revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Teri Garr |image = Teri Garr - signed.jpg |imagesize = |alt = |caption = Signed photo of Garr in the 1970s |birth_name = Teri Ann Garr |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1944|12|11|}} |birth_place = [[Lakewood, Ohio]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |occupation = Actress, dancer, singer, comedian |years_active = 1963–2011 |spouse = {{marriage|John O'Neil
|1993|1996|end=divorced}} |partner = [[Roger Birnbaum]] (1979–1983)
David Kipper (1983–1990)}} '''Teri Ann Garr''' is a retired American actress, singer, dancer and voice artist. She began her career as a teenager with small roles in television and film, in the early 1960s including appearances as a dancer in nine [[Elvis Presley]] musicals. She is perhaps best known for appearing in comedy films, including ''[[Young Frankenstein]]'' (1974), ''[[Mr. Mom]]'' (1983) and ''[[Tootsie]]'' (1982) which earned her a nomination for the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] for her role Sandra "Sandy" Lester.{{Cite news|url=https://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1983|title=The 55th Academy Awards {{!}} 1983|work=Oscars.org {{!}} Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|access-date=2018-04-30|language=en}} Her quick banter led to Garr being a regular guest on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' and [[David Letterman]]'s late night talk shows. She also appeared on television as [[List of Friends characters#Phoebe Abbott|Phoebe Abbott]] in three episodes of the sitcom ''[[Friends]]'' (1997–98). Garr has been largely retired from performing since 2007.{{cn|date=January 2018}} ==Early life== Teri Ann Garr was born in [[Lakewood, Ohio]], a suburb of [[Cleveland]]. Her father, Eddie Garr (born Edward Leo Gonnoud, 1900-1956), was a [[vaudeville]] performer, comedian, and actor whose career peaked when he briefly took over the lead role in the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] drama ''[[Tobacco Road (play)|Tobacco Road]]''. He changed his surname before Teri's birth. Her mother, Phyllis Lind Garr (1909-1999) (born Emma Schmotzer), was a dancer, a [[The Rockettes |Rockette]], [[Wardrobe supervisor|wardrobe mistress]], and model.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/22/Teri-Garr.html|title=Teri Garr profile|website=Filmreference.com|accessdate=December 11, 2016}}{{cite news|first=Edward|last=Guthmann|date=January 7, 2004|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2004/01/07/DDGD343TKC1.DTL&type=printable|title=As acting jobs dwindle, Teri Garr takes up her pen|work=San Francisco Chronicle}}{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/g/GooglePM/BG/lib00065,0EADEAD18E1E4492.html|website=Boston.com|title=Local Search|publisher=newsbank.com|accessdate=September 5, 2017}} Her father was of Irish descent and her maternal grandparents were Austrian immigrants.{{cite book|last1=Garr|first1=Teri|first2=Henriette|last2=Mantel|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=la32abcC6_4C&pg=PA68|title=Speedbumps: Flooring it Through Hollywood|publisher=Hudson Street Press|date=November 2005|page=68|isbn=1-59463-007-0|quote=Autobiography by Teri Garr}} ==Early career== Early in her career she was credited as '''Terri Garr''', '''Terry Garr''', '''Teri Hope''', or '''Terry Carr'''. Her movie debut was as an extra in ''A Swingin' Affair'' (1963). During her senior year she auditioned for the cast of the Los Angeles road company production of ''[[West Side Story]]'', where she met one of the most important people in her early career, [[David Winters (choreographer)|David Winters]], who became her friend, dance teacher, and mentor. Winters cast her in many of his early movies and projects.{{cite web|url=http://www.abilitymagazine.com/Garr/teri_garr.html|title=Teri Garr - My Life So Far|work=Ability Magazine|access-date=April 7, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927220532/http://www.abilitymagazine.com/Garr/teri_garr.html|archivedate=September 27, 2007|df=mdy-all}} [[File:TeriGarr HectorElizondo.jpg|thumb|right|Garr and [[Hector Elizondo]] on the set of ''[[Perfect Alibi (1995 film)|Perfect Alibi]]'' with director [[Kevin Meyer]]]] Garr began as a background [[Go-go dancing|go go dancer]] in uncredited roles in youth-oriented films and TV shows choreographed by Winters,{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0935916|title=David Winters biodata|website=IMDb.com|publisher=Internet Movie Database|access-date=September 6, 2017}} including ''[[Pajama Party (film)|Pajama Party]]'' (a [[beach party film]]), the ''[[T.A.M.I. Show]]'', ''[[Shindig!]]'', ''[[Shivaree (TV series)|Shivaree]]'', ''[[Hullabaloo (TV series)|Hullabaloo]]'', ''[[Movin' with Nancy]]'', and nine Elvis Presley features (many of which were also choreographed by Winters, including Presley's most profitable film, ''[[Viva Las Vegas]]''. When asked in a magazine interview about how she landed jobs in so many Presley films, Garr answered, "One of the dancers in the road show of ''[[West Side Story]]'' ([[David Winters (choreographer)|David Winters]]) started to choreograph movies, and whatever job he got, I was one of the girls he'd hire. So he was chosen to do ''Viva Las Vegas''. That was my first movie."{{cite web|url=http://www.davidwinters.net/archives2.htm|date=2004|title=Talkin' 'bout my g-g-g-generation|website=David Winters.net|access-date=April 7, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040302004146/http://www.davidwinters.net/archives2.htm|archivedate=March 2, 2004|df=mdy-all}} ==Film and television== Her first speaking role in a motion picture was a brief appearance as a [[damsel in distress]] in the [[The Monkees|Monkees]] film ''[[Head (film)|Head]]'' (1968), written by [[Jack Nicholson]]. She landed her first significant motion picture role in [[Francis Ford Coppola]]'s ''[[The Conversation]]'' (1974). Her career breakthrough came in the [[Mel Brooks]] comedy ''[[Young Frankenstein]]'' (also 1974) as Inga. She appeared in a string of highly successful films, including ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'' (1977) as the wife of [[Richard Dreyfuss]]'s character, ''[[Oh, God! (film)|Oh, God!]]'' (1977) as the wife of [[John Denver]]'s character, ''[[The Black Stallion (film)|The Black Stallion]]'' (1979) as the mother of [[Kelly Reno]]'s character, ''[[Mr. Mom]]'' (1983) as the wife of [[Michael Keaton]]'s character, ''[[After Hours (film)|After Hours]]'' (1985), and ''[[Let It Ride (film)|Let It Ride]]'' (1989), also opposite Dreyfuss. Garr was nominated for an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for her supporting role as [[Dustin Hoffman]]'s character's actress friend in ''[[Tootsie]]'' (1982).{{IMDb name|414|Teri Garr}} She often appeared on television. She began as a go-go dancer on several musical [[variety show]]s, along with friend [[Toni Basil]], such as ''[[Shindig!]]'' and ''[[Hullabaloo (TV series)|Hullabaloo]]''. In 1966 Garr made one appearance on ''[[Batman (TV series)|Batman]]'' (episode 7, uncredited). In 1968, she appeared in both ''[[The Andy Griffith Show]]'' and ''[[Mayberry R.F.D.]]{{cite episode|season=01|number=12|series=[[Mayberry R.F.D.]]|date=1968}}'' and was in two episodes of ''[[It Takes a Thief (1968 TV series)|It Takes a Thief]]''. In 1968, she was featured as secretary Roberta Lincoln in the ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'' episode "[[Assignment: Earth]]", designed as a [[Backdoor pilots|backdoor pilot]] episode for a new series which was not commissioned. In the early 1970s, she was a regular cast member on ''[[The Sonny and Cher Comedy Hour]]'', dancing and acting in comedy sketches. She had a recurring role on ''[[McCloud (TV series)|McCloud]]'', and appeared on ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]'', ''[[The Bob Newhart Show]]'', ''[[The Odd Couple (1970 TV series)|The Odd Couple]]'', ''[[Maude (TV series)|Maude]]'', ''[[Barnaby Jones]]'', and ''[[Paul Sand in Friends and Lovers]]''. She hosted ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' three times (in 1980, 1983, and 1985), and was a frequent visitor on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]''. As a recurring guest on ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'', she was renowned for her unscripted banter with [[David Letterman]], who once goaded her into showering in his office while the camera rolled.{{cite news|url=http://www.abilitymagazine.com/Garr/teri_garr.html|title=Teri Garr–My Life So Far|publisher=Ability Magazine|year=2007|issue=1|accessdate=June 21, 2007|first=Jacob|last=Wascalus|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927220532/http://www.abilitymagazine.com/Garr/teri_garr.html|archivedate=September 27, 2007|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/show_info/pants/Letterman25.pdf|title=David Letterman - 25 Years and Still Going Strong |publisher=[[CBS]]|accessdate=June 21, 2007| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620154551/http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/show_info/pants/Letterman25.pdf|archivedate=June 20, 2007}} She landed a role as recurring character [[Phoebe Abbott]] in ''[[Friends]]'', the estranged birth mother of [[Phoebe Buffay]]. ==Personal life== [[File:Teri Garr at the AIDS Project Los Angeles (APLA) benefit cropped.jpg|thumb|Garr at the [[AIDS Project Los Angeles]] (APLA) benefit, September 1990]] Garr's daughter, Molly O'Neil, was born in November 1993. Garr married contractor John O'Neil on the day their adopted daughter was born. Garr and O'Neil divorced in 1996. ===Health=== In October 2002, Garr publicly confirmed that she had been diagnosed with [[multiple sclerosis]].{{cite web|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/SHOWBIZ/News/10/08/teri.garr.ms|title=Teri Garr reveals she has multiple sclerosis|date=October 9, 2002|accessdate=June 5, 2007|work=CNN|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AGWfZ8xB?url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/SHOWBIZ/News/10/08/teri.garr.ms|archivedate=August 28, 2012|df=mdy-all}} After years of uncertainty and secrecy surrounding her diagnosis, Garr explained her reasons for deciding to go public: "I'm telling my story for the first time so I can help people. I can help people know they aren't alone and tell them there are reasons to be optimistic because, today, treatment options are available." In interviews, she has commented that she first started noticing symptoms while in New York filming ''[[Tootsie]]''. After disclosing her condition, she became a National Ambassador for the [[National Multiple Sclerosis Society]] and National Chair for the Society's Women Against MS program (WAMS).{{cite web|url=http://www.news-medical.net/?id=1021|title=Actress Teri Garr named as multiple sclerosis national chairwoman|accessdate=June 5, 2007|date=April 29, 2004|work=News-Medical.net}} In November 2005, Garr was honored as the society's Ambassador of the Year. This honor had been given only four times since the society was founded.{{cn|date=September 2017}} ''Closer'' reported in 2015 that she credited her positive attitude and support of her family as helping her fight the disease.{{cite web|url=http://www.closerweekly.com/posts/exclusive-teri-garr-battles-multiple-sclerosis-stays-positive-67607|title=Teri Garr Battles Multiple Sclerosis With a Positive Outlook With the Help of Her Family|work=Closer Weekly|date=August 23, 2015|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} In 2006, Garr suffered a ruptured [[brain aneurysm]].{{cite web|first=Michelle|last=Tan|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20005817,00.html|title=Teri Garr Recovering from Brain Aneurysm|accessdate=June 5, 2007|work=People|date=January 2, 2007}} After therapy, she regained speech and motor skills, and, in 2008 appeared on ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' to promote ''[[Expired]]'', a 2007 film in which she played a set of twins.{{cite web|title=David Letterman-Teri Garr-June-19-2008|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XYq5fk69dIY|publisher=Youtube|accessdate=7 November 2017}} ==Retirement== Garr has not acted in films or television since 2007, though she did publicly appear at the 19th Annual Race to Erase MS (multiple sclerosis) event in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/teri-garr-and-nancy-davis-attend-the-19th-annual-race-to-news-photo/144765017|title=19th Annual Race To Erase MS|publisher=[[Getty Images]]|date=May 18, 2012|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} Garr appeared on ''[[The Moth]] Radio Hour'' broadcast of December 9, 2009 to tell a humorous reminiscence entitled "Wake Up Call".{{cite web|url=https://themoth.org/stories/wake-up-call|title=Wake Up Call|publisher=''[[The Moth]]''|accessdate=January 13, 2018|date=December 9, 2009}} ==Awards and nominations== ;Academy Award (Oscar) *1983: Nominated for "[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]]" in ''[[Tootsie]]'' ;British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) *1984: Nominated for "[[BAFTA Award|Best Supporting Actress]]" in ''Tootsie'' ;National Society of Film Critics, USA *1983: Third Place "[[National Society of Film Critics|Best Supporting Actress]]" in ''Tootsie'' ;National Board of Review, USA *1994 Winner: "[[National Board of Review|Best Acting Ensemble]]" in ''[[Prêt-à-Porter (film)|Prêt-à-Porter]]'' ;Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy & Horror Films, USA *1978: Nominated for "[[Saturn Award|Best Supporting Actress]]" in ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'' ;CableACE Awards *1983 Nominated for "[[CableACE Award|Actress in a Dramatic Presentation]]" in ''[[Faerie Tale Theatre]]'' For episode "The Tale of the Frog Prince". ==Selected filmography== {{colbegin}} *''[[Fun in Acapulco]]'' (1963), backup dancer *''[[Kissin' Cousins]]'' (1964), backup dancer
